news_summary: Progress in human rights is marked by Uganda's pioneering peace journalism awards, England's commitment to expanding foster care with 10,000 new places, and the reopening of Rafah providing critical access for patients despite ongoing aid challenges.

news_summary_es: Los avances en materia de derechos humanos se reflejan en los premios pioneros de periodismo por la paz de Uganda, el compromiso de Inglaterra de ampliar el acogimiento familiar con 10 000 nuevas plazas y la reapertura de Rafah, que proporciona un acceso fundamental a los pacientes a pesar de los continuos retos en materia de ayuda humanitaria.

articles.title: Uganda’s first peace journalism awards redefine the media landscape
articles.summary: The PJF’s framework seeks to move the media beyond sensationalism toward peace and development-oriented reporting, emphasizing early identification of conflict triggers and the promotion of non-violent responses.
articles.content:
This article by Justine Muboka was originally published by Peace News Network on January 21, 2026. An edited version is republished on Global Voices as part of a content partnership agreement.

On December 19, 2025, the air in Gulu City, Uganda, carried more than the warmth of the dry season; It carried the weight of history. At the premises of Gulu Women’s Economic Development and Globalization (GWED-G), the Peace Journalism Foundation (PJF) Uganda–East Africa launched the first edition of the Peace Journalism Awards. This initiative is designed to recognize journalism that contributes to peace, social cohesion, and development.

Held under the theme “Celebrating Peace, Progress, and the Power of the Media,” the awards marked a shift in how journalistic excellence is honored. Rather than relying on self-submitted applications, the PJF introduced a bottom-up, community-led nomination model. This approach is grounded in the belief that the grassroots communities — those most affected by journalism — are best placed to assess its value and impact.

The bottom-up model: Why grassroots organizing matters

In traditional journalism awards, recognition is often driven by applications and the submission of selected stories. By contrast, the Peace Journalism Awards rely on community validators and partner organizations, including GWED-G, to identify journalists whose work has made a demonstrable difference in post-conflict contexts such as Northern Uganda. The model is expected to expand to other regions, including Karamoja, Bunyoro, and the Rwenzori sub-region.

This approach elevates what might otherwise remain invisible. It recognizes reporters in remote villages who use conflict-sensitive language to defuse tensions over land disputes. It also highlights broadcasters who create space for dialogue where violence might otherwise erupt. Under this model, excellence is measured not by prominence but by verifiable community impact — reduced tensions, informed dialogue, and steps toward reconciliation.

Mega FM and the legacy of Gloria Laker

One of the most resonant moments of the ceremony was the Peace Radio Award presentation to Mega FM 102.2. The award’s significance is rooted in history. During the height of the Lord’s Resistance Army (LRA) conflict in Northern Uganda, radio played a critical role as a communication bridge. Radio Freedom, established with the involvement of the Uganda People’s Defence Force (UPDF), provided information to displaced communities. It aired messages urging combatants to take advantage of the presidential amnesty. According to publicly acknowledged accounts, these broadcasts contributed to the voluntary return of thousands of former combatants.

Radio Freedom later evolved into Mega FM. Today, under the management of Irene Atek, Mega FM is widely regarded as a platform for dialogue, information sharing, and community engagement in Northern Uganda — illustrating how media can contribute to stabilization and recovery when used responsibly.

Closely linked to this history is the Excellence in Peace Reporting Award, established in honor of Gloria Laker Adiiki Aciro, a 2025 Luxembourg Peace Prize laureate. Laker’s career spans frontline reporting during the LRA conflict to regional mentorship and training, reflecting a transition from conflict coverage to peace-oriented journalism.

The inaugural recipient of this award was Rosemary Anena of Vision Group (Radio Rupiny), who came from the same station where Laker began her career. Her achievement symbolized an intergenerational and “woman-to-woman” transfer of responsibility. In a region where women’s voices were once marginalized, Anena’s work highlights constructive reporting, community resilience, and inclusive narratives.

Talk shows as spaces for de-escalation

The awards also recognized the evolving role of talk show hosts in fragile contexts. Otim Steven Acire, popularly known as “Palaring” of Radio Pacis, was named Talk Show Host of the Year for Northern Uganda. His nomination, submitted by GWED-G, highlighted the importance of mediation skills in live broadcasting.

While conventional journalism emphasizes detachment, the Peace Journalism Foundation underscored that, in high-stakes talk shows, responsible moderation can help prevent escalation. Palaring is recognized for managing tense discussions and ensuring respectful engagement among guests with opposing views. Reflecting on a recent broadcast involving multiple political candidates, he noted that deliberate use of mediation techniques helped maintain calm and constructive dialogue throughout the program.

Following the January 2026 elections, such conflict-sensitive approaches are increasingly relevant. The PJF’s framework seeks to move the media beyond sensationalism toward peace- and development-oriented reporting, emphasizing early identification of conflict triggers and promoting nonviolent responses.

Empowering the future: Youth as peace actors

Another defining moment of the evening was the recognition of the Youth Peace Activist of the Year. Historically, young people in periods of political tension have often been portrayed as vulnerable to manipulation. The PJF’s decision to center youth in peacebuilding reframed this narrative.

Uganda has one of the world’s youngest populations, with over 75 percent of the country being under 35 years old. When Senior Mercy Florence received the award, she emphasized the significance of being recognized in a country where young people constitute the majority of the population. Her acknowledgment sent a message that young people can be agents of social cohesion and constructive engagement. By spotlighting such initiatives, the PJF aims to encourage peaceful participation during the 2026 election cycle and beyond.

Media, responsibility, and protection

Several speakers used the occasion to reflect on the broader role of media in society. Pamela Angwech, executive director of GWED-G, emphasized that media should be treated as an essential public good rather than a luxury. She noted:

Media should reach all communities, including displaced persons. We should promote peace-oriented and responsible journalism.

Angwech also highlighted the importance of fair labor practices within media houses and the need to appreciate journalists whose work supports the industry. She stressed that protecting journalists and upholding freedom of expression — within the bounds of the law — is fundamental to an informed society.

Gloria Laker Adiiki Aciro, speaking in her capacity as Director of the Peace Journalism Foundation, urged journalists to prioritize development-focused reporting and to learn from regional history.

“It is us who can create a society, so let us promote peaceful development,” she said, referencing the importance of avoiding post-election violence experienced elsewhere in the region.

Speaking on behalf of the security sector, Captain David Kamya, the Fourth Division Uganda People’s Defence Force (UPDF) public information officer, reflected on the human cost of conflict and called for reporting that emphasizes unity and shared responsibility.

“Let us report unity over division, humanity over hatred,” he said, noting that irresponsible reporting can have consequences for entire communities.

Local government also weighed in. Peter Banya, the Gulu City resident city commissioner for Laroo–Pece Division, encouraged journalists to highlight positive developments in the region to balance narratives and support recovery.

The digital frontier: Looking toward 2026 and beyond

Building on the success of the first edition, the PJF announced plans to expand the awards in 2026 to include Digital and Individual Peacebuilders, such as bloggers and online content creators. As information increasingly circulates across digital platforms, these categories aim to recognize efforts that counter misinformation and promote responsible online discourse.

The 2025 Peace Journalism Awards positioned ethical, impact-driven journalism as a cornerstone of sustainable peace. As Gloria Laker noted, supporting peace journalism is an investment in the infrastructure of peace — one that benefits communities, democratic processes, and regional stability. The 2025 laureates included Benson Ongom (Journalist of the Year), Dennis Ojwee (Lifetime Achievement Award), and Otim Steven Acire (Talk Show Host of the Year). They represent a media landscape that prioritizes responsibility over sensationalism. Their recognition affirms a growing consensus: When journalism chooses peace, society as a whole is strengthened.
articles.reasoning: The article describes the launch of Uganda's first Peace Journalism Awards, which promote responsible media reporting that fosters peace, social cohesion, and development in post-conflict regions. The initiative has broad societal impact by encouraging conflict-sensitive journalism, empowering youth as peace actors, and supporting democratic processes, thus contributing to regional stability and reducing violence.
articles.personality_title: Uganda launches first Peace Journalism Awards to promote responsible reporting
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Uganda has faced long periods of conflict, especially in the northern regions. Media coverage has often focused on violence and tension, which can sometimes make conflicts worse. To change this, the Peace Journalism Foundation (PJF) started a new awards program to encourage journalism that supports peace and development.

**What happened** – On December 19, 2025, the first Peace Journalism Awards were held in Gulu City, Uganda. Unlike usual awards where journalists apply themselves, this program lets local communities nominate reporters who have helped reduce conflict or promote dialogue. The event honored radio stations, reporters, and talk show hosts who use words carefully to calm tensions and encourage peaceful conversations. For example, Mega FM 102.2 was recognized for its role in helping communities recover after war, and talk show host Otim Steven Acire was praised for managing calm debates during politically sensitive times.

**Impact** – This awards program is unique because it focuses on the real effects journalism has on communities, especially in areas recovering from conflict. It highlights reporters who work in remote villages and use language that helps solve problems instead of making them worse. It also changes how young people are seen, showing them as important peacebuilders rather than troublemakers. By promoting peace-focused media, the awards help build trust, support elections without violence, and encourage respectful discussion.

**What's next step** – The Peace Journalism Foundation plans to expand the awards in 2026 to include digital journalists and online content creators. This will recognize those who fight misinformation on social media and promote peaceful conversations online. The program aims to keep encouraging responsible journalism across Uganda and other regions, helping more communities find peaceful ways to solve their problems.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Uganda’s Peace Journalism Awards celebrate media that helps communities heal and grow by promoting peaceful, responsible reporting that reduces conflict and supports development.
articles.personality_title_fr: L’Ouganda lance les premiers prix du journalisme de paix pour encourager un reportage responsable
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – L’Ouganda a connu de longues périodes de conflit, notamment dans le nord du pays. Les médias ont souvent mis l’accent sur la violence, ce qui peut aggraver les tensions. Pour changer cela, la Fondation du journalisme de paix (PJF) a lancé un nouveau programme de prix pour encourager un journalisme qui soutient la paix et le développement.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le 19 décembre 2025, les premiers prix du journalisme de paix ont eu lieu à Gulu, en Ouganda. Contrairement aux prix habituels où les journalistes postulent eux-mêmes, ce programme permet aux communautés locales de nommer des reporters qui ont aidé à réduire les conflits ou à promouvoir le dialogue. L’événement a récompensé des radios, journalistes et animateurs d’émissions qui utilisent un langage apaisant pour calmer les tensions et encourager des conversations pacifiques. Par exemple, Mega FM 102.2 a été reconnu pour son rôle dans la reconstruction après la guerre, et l’animateur Otim Steven Acire pour sa gestion calme des débats politiques.

**Impact** – Ce programme est unique car il se concentre sur les effets réels du journalisme dans les communautés, surtout celles qui se remettent du conflit. Il met en valeur les journalistes travaillant dans des villages isolés et utilisant un langage qui aide à résoudre les problèmes. Il change aussi la perception des jeunes, les montrant comme des acteurs de paix plutôt que des fauteurs de troubles. En promouvant un journalisme axé sur la paix, les prix renforcent la confiance, soutiennent des élections sans violence et encouragent le respect dans les discussions.

**Prochaines étapes** – La Fondation du journalisme de paix prévoit d’étendre les prix en 2026 pour inclure les journalistes numériques et créateurs de contenu en ligne. Cela permettra de reconnaître ceux qui luttent contre la désinformation sur les réseaux sociaux et encouragent des échanges pacifiques en ligne. Le programme vise à continuer de promouvoir un journalisme responsable à travers l’Ouganda et d’autres régions, aidant plus de communautés à trouver des solutions pacifiques.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Les prix du journalisme de paix en Ouganda célèbrent les médias qui aident les communautés à guérir et à se développer grâce à un reportage responsable et pacifique qui réduit les conflits et soutient le développement.
articles.personality_title_es: Uganda lanza los primeros premios de periodismo de paz para promover reportajes responsables
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Uganda ha vivido largos períodos de conflicto, especialmente en el norte del país. Los medios de comunicación a menudo se enfocaban en la violencia, lo que a veces empeora las tensiones. Para cambiar esto, la Fundación de Periodismo de Paz (PJF) inició un programa de premios para fomentar un periodismo que apoye la paz y el desarrollo.

**Qué pasó** – El 19 de diciembre de 2025, se celebraron en Gulu, Uganda, los primeros Premios de Periodismo de Paz. A diferencia de otros premios donde los periodistas se postulan, este programa permite que las comunidades locales nominen a reporteros que hayan ayudado a reducir conflictos o promover el diálogo. El evento reconoció a estaciones de radio, periodistas y presentadores que usan un lenguaje que calma tensiones y fomenta conversaciones pacíficas. Por ejemplo, Mega FM 102.2 fue premiada por su papel en la recuperación tras la guerra, y el presentador Otim Steven Acire fue reconocido por manejar debates políticos con calma.

**Impacto** – Este programa es único porque se centra en los efectos reales del periodismo en las comunidades, especialmente en zonas que se recuperan de conflictos. Destaca a reporteros en pueblos remotos que usan un lenguaje que ayuda a resolver problemas. También cambia la forma en que se ve a los jóvenes, mostrándolos como constructores de paz y no como problemas. Al promover medios enfocados en la paz, los premios ayudan a construir confianza, apoyan elecciones sin violencia y fomentan el respeto en las discusiones.

**Próximos pasos** – La Fundación de Periodismo de Paz planea ampliar los premios en 2026 para incluir periodistas digitales y creadores de contenido en línea. Esto reconocerá a quienes combaten la desinformación en redes sociales y promueven conversaciones pacíficas en internet. El programa busca seguir promoviendo un periodismo responsable en Uganda y otras regiones, ayudando a más comunidades a encontrar soluciones pacíficas.

**Resumen en una frase** – Los Premios de Periodismo de Paz de Uganda reconocen a los medios que ayudan a las comunidades a sanar y crecer mediante reportajes responsables y pacíficos que reducen conflictos y apoyan el desarrollo.

articles.title: Government pledges 10,000 new foster care places in England
articles.summary: Rule changes aim to create thousands of new foster places and help full-time workers.
articles.content: The proposals will also offer help for people to make home improvements, such as extending their homes, and increase practical day-to-day support for families through schemes like the Mockingbird programme, which is run by the Fostering Network. It brings groups of foster families together so they can provide advice, support and respite care for each other, like an extended family.
articles.reasoning: The government is implementing policy changes to create 10,000 new foster care places, providing significant support to foster families and children in need. This has broad societal impact by improving child welfare and support systems, with detailed measures like home improvement assistance and community support programs.
articles.personality_title: England plans 10,000 new foster care places to support children and families
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – England faces a growing need for foster care places, where children who cannot live with their birth families are cared for by foster families. Finding enough homes and support for these children is a challenge.

**What happened** – The government announced new rules to create 10,000 additional foster care places. These changes include helping foster families improve their homes, such as by adding extra rooms. They will also provide more day-to-day support through programs like the Mockingbird scheme, which connects groups of foster families so they can share advice and care for each other.

**Impact** – This plan is important because it offers more homes for children who need safe and caring environments. The support programs help foster families manage their responsibilities better by creating a community where they can rely on each other. This helps children feel more secure and cared for.

**What's next step** – The government will begin putting these rule changes into action and work with organizations like the Fostering Network to expand programs such as Mockingbird. Over time, they hope to see more families becoming foster carers and better support for children in care.

**One-sentence takeaway** – England’s new plan aims to add 10,000 foster places and strengthen support networks to improve care for children in need.
articles.personality_title_fr: L’Angleterre prévoit 10 000 nouvelles places en famille d’accueil pour soutenir les enfants et les familles
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – En Angleterre, la demande de places en famille d’accueil, où les enfants ne pouvant pas vivre avec leurs parents sont pris en charge, augmente. Trouver assez de foyers et de soutien pour ces enfants est un défi.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le gouvernement a annoncé de nouvelles règles pour créer 10 000 places supplémentaires en famille d’accueil. Ces changements incluent une aide pour que les familles puissent améliorer leur maison, par exemple en ajoutant des pièces. Ils offriront aussi plus de soutien quotidien grâce à des programmes comme le dispositif Mockingbird, qui réunit des groupes de familles d’accueil pour qu’elles s’entraident.

**Impact** – Ce plan est important parce qu’il offre plus de foyers sûrs et bienveillants aux enfants qui en ont besoin. Les programmes de soutien aident les familles d’accueil à mieux gérer leurs responsabilités en créant une communauté d’entraide. Cela aide les enfants à se sentir plus en sécurité.

**Prochaine étape** – Le gouvernement commencera à appliquer ces nouvelles règles et travaillera avec des organisations comme le Fostering Network pour développer des programmes comme Mockingbird. À terme, ils espèrent que plus de familles deviendront familles d’accueil et que le soutien aux enfants sera renforcé.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Le nouveau plan de l’Angleterre vise à ajouter 10 000 places en famille d’accueil et à renforcer les réseaux de soutien pour améliorer la prise en charge des enfants dans le besoin.
articles.personality_title_es: Inglaterra planea 10,000 nuevos lugares de acogida para apoyar a niños y familias
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – En Inglaterra, hay una creciente necesidad de lugares en familias de acogida, donde niños que no pueden vivir con sus padres biológicos son cuidados por familias de acogida. Encontrar suficientes hogares y apoyo para estos niños es un reto.

**Qué pasó** – El gobierno anunció nuevas reglas para crear 10,000 lugares adicionales en familias de acogida. Estos cambios incluyen ayudar a las familias a mejorar sus casas, como agregar habitaciones extra. También ofrecerán más apoyo diario a través de programas como Mockingbird, que une grupos de familias de acogida para que puedan compartir consejos y cuidarse entre ellas.

**Impacto** – Este plan es importante porque ofrece más hogares seguros y cariñosos para los niños que los necesitan. Los programas de apoyo ayudan a las familias de acogida a manejar mejor sus responsabilidades creando una comunidad donde pueden apoyarse mutuamente. Esto ayuda a que los niños se sientan más seguros y cuidados.

**Próximo paso** – El gobierno comenzará a implementar estos cambios y trabajará con organizaciones como la Fostering Network para ampliar programas como Mockingbird. Con el tiempo, esperan que más familias se conviertan en cuidadores y que haya mejor apoyo para los niños en acogida.

**Resumen en una frase** – El nuevo plan de Inglaterra busca añadir 10,000 lugares de acogida y fortalecer las redes de apoyo para mejorar el cuidado de los niños que lo necesitan.

articles.title: Rafah reopening offers lifeline for patients, but aid flow still far from enough
articles.summary: The partial reopening of the Rafah crossing between Gaza and Egypt has allowed a small number of people to leave and return to the Strip – including critically ill patients – but the UN has warned that far more is needed for the crossing to function as a genuine humanitarian lifeline.
articles.content:
Briefing journalists in New York on Tuesday, UN Spokesperson Stéphane Dujarric said UN relief chief Tom Fletcher welcomed the reopening but stressed that it must go beyond limited movements of people.

Tweet URL

“Rafah must function as a real humanitarian corridor so we can have a surge in aid deliveries,” Mr. Fletcher said, underlining that current access remains insufficient to meet vast and growing needs across Gaza.

Only five evacuated

The World Health Organization (WHO) confirmed that when the crossing briefly opened on Monday, it facilitated the evacuation of five patients and seven companions from Gaza into Egypt.

WHO said its role focused on ensuring the safe transfer of patients from inside Gaza to the Rafah crossing, after security clearance was obtained.

Speaking separately to reporters in Geneva, WHO spokesperson Christian Lindmeier described the evacuations as the first through Rafah in months, calling them “the start of a process” and a test of whether a sustained flow could be established: “obviously we need many more,” he said.

According to WHO, more than 18,500 patients in Gaza still require specialised medical care that is no longer available in the Strip, including people suffering from heavy trauma wounds, cancer and chronic diseases such as diabetes.

‘Human disaster’

“18,500 waiting, five managed to get out…That’s not just math – it’s a human disaster for those having to wait.”

He also highlighted the tragedy of patients who have died while awaiting evacuation, despite life-saving treatment being available just beyond the border. A major challenge, he added, remains finding countries willing to receive patients.

Meanwhile, further movements are expected through Rafah in the coming days.

WHO continues to facilitate the transfer of patients and their companions, while the UN Development Programme (UNDP) is providing bus transportation for returnees from an internal checkpoint to Nasser hospital in Khan Younis.

At the hospital, OCHA and several UN and NGO partners have established a reception area offering medical, psychosocial and referral services.

UN News The World Health Organisation is overseeing the transportation of patients to the Rafah border crossing on the first day of its reopening.

Widespread needs

Beyond medical evacuations, UN agencies and humanitarian partners are continuing to respond to widespread needs across Gaza.

Food security partners report that by the end of January, around 25 organisations were producing and distributing 1.7 million meals every day through more than 180 kitchens, with over half a million meals in the north and 1.2 million in the south.

Partners also brought in around 650 metric tonnes of animal feed during January, now being distributed to livestock holders and donkey owners who support essential services.

Schooling and shelter

In the shelter sector, more than 83,500 families received assistance last month, including tents, mattresses, kitchen utensils and warm clothing, though partners stress the urgent need to move towards more sustainable housing solutions.

Education partners are likewise working to expand learning capacity by setting up new spaces and supporting community-led initiatives, as supplies gradually arrive.

Despite these efforts, the UN has reiterated that without sustained access through crossings such as Rafah, humanitarian needs will continue to outpace the response.
articles.source: UN News - Global perspective Human stories
articles.reasoning: The article reports on the partial reopening of the Rafah crossing, enabling the evacuation of critically ill patients from Gaza and the delivery of humanitarian aid. This event has a significant positive real-world impact by providing a vital humanitarian corridor, addressing urgent medical and basic needs for a large population under crisis. The story focuses on this single, meaningful development with detailed context about ongoing challenges and efforts, making it an inspiring example of humanitarian progress despite difficulties.
articles.personality_title: Partial Rafah crossing reopening helps critical patients, but aid remains limited
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The Rafah crossing is a border point between Gaza and Egypt. It has been mostly closed for months, blocking many people and aid from moving in or out of Gaza. Gaza faces a big humanitarian crisis, with many people needing medical help and basic supplies.

**What happened** – On Monday, the Rafah crossing partially reopened for the first time in months. This allowed five very sick patients and seven companions to leave Gaza for treatment in Egypt. The World Health Organization (WHO) helped organize their safe transfer. The United Nations (UN) said this is only a small start and that much more needs to be done to allow more people and aid to pass through.

**Impact** – This reopening is important because over 18,500 patients in Gaza need special medical care that is not available there. Many have serious illnesses like cancer or injuries. Only a few have been able to leave, which means many continue to suffer or even die waiting. The reopening shows it is possible to move people out safely, but it also highlights how urgent it is to increase these efforts.

**What's next step** – More movements through Rafah are expected soon. The WHO and other UN groups will keep helping patients travel and provide support at hospitals. Aid groups are also delivering food, shelter, and other help inside Gaza. The hope is that the crossing will become a regular humanitarian path to bring in more supplies and allow more people to leave when needed.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The partial reopening of the Rafah crossing offers a crucial but limited chance for Gaza’s sickest patients to get care and signals the need for more aid and access.
articles.personality_title_fr: La réouverture partielle de Rafah aide les patients critiques, mais l’aide reste insuffisante
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Le point de passage de Rafah est une frontière entre Gaza et l’Égypte. Il est presque fermé depuis des mois, empêchant de nombreuses personnes et aides d’entrer ou de sortir de Gaza. Gaza fait face à une grave crise humanitaire, avec beaucoup de gens ayant besoin d’aide médicale et de fournitures de base.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Lundi, le passage de Rafah a été partiellement rouvert pour la première fois depuis des mois. Cela a permis à cinq patients très malades et sept accompagnants de quitter Gaza pour recevoir un traitement en Égypte. L’Organisation mondiale de la santé (OMS) a aidé à organiser leur transfert en toute sécurité. L’ONU a déclaré que ce n’est qu’un petit début et qu’il faut faire beaucoup plus pour permettre à plus de personnes et d’aides de passer.

**Impact** – Cette réouverture est importante car plus de 18 500 patients à Gaza ont besoin de soins médicaux spécialisés non disponibles sur place. Beaucoup souffrent de maladies graves comme le cancer ou de blessures. Seuls quelques-uns ont pu partir, ce qui signifie que beaucoup continuent à souffrir ou même à mourir en attendant. Cette réouverture montre qu’il est possible de faire passer des personnes en sécurité, mais souligne aussi l’urgence d’intensifier ces efforts.

**Prochaine étape** – D’autres passages par Rafah sont attendus bientôt. L’OMS et d’autres groupes de l’ONU continueront d’aider les patients à voyager et fournir un soutien dans les hôpitaux. Les groupes d’aide livrent aussi nourriture, abris et autres aides à Gaza. L’espoir est que ce passage devienne un chemin humanitaire régulier pour faire entrer plus de fournitures et permettre à plus de personnes de partir si besoin.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – La réouverture partielle du passage de Rafah offre une chance cruciale mais limitée aux patients les plus malades de Gaza pour obtenir des soins et montre la nécessité d’augmenter l’aide et l’accès.
articles.personality_title_es: Reapertura parcial de Rafah ayuda a pacientes críticos, pero la ayuda sigue siendo limitada
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – El cruce de Rafah es un punto fronterizo entre Gaza y Egipto. Ha estado cerrado casi todo el tiempo durante meses, bloqueando que muchas personas y ayuda puedan entrar o salir de Gaza. Gaza enfrenta una gran crisis humanitaria, con muchas personas que necesitan ayuda médica y suministros básicos.

**Qué pasó** – El lunes, el cruce de Rafah se reabrió parcialmente por primera vez en meses. Esto permitió que cinco pacientes muy enfermos y siete acompañantes salieran de Gaza para recibir tratamiento en Egipto. La Organización Mundial de la Salud (OMS) ayudó a organizar su traslado seguro. Las Naciones Unidas dijeron que esto es solo un pequeño comienzo y que se necesita hacer mucho más para permitir que más personas y ayuda puedan pasar.

**Impacto** – Esta reapertura es importante porque más de 18,500 pacientes en Gaza necesitan atención médica especial que no está disponible allí. Muchos tienen enfermedades graves como cáncer o heridas. Solo unos pocos han podido salir, lo que significa que muchos siguen sufriendo o incluso muriendo mientras esperan. La reapertura muestra que es posible mover a las personas de manera segura, pero también destaca la urgencia de aumentar estos esfuerzos.

**Próximo paso** – Se esperan más movimientos a través de Rafah pronto. La OMS y otros grupos de la ONU seguirán ayudando a los pacientes a viajar y brindando apoyo en hospitales. Los grupos de ayuda también están entregando comida, refugio y otras ayudas dentro de Gaza.
